doc.field: Designed by Sir George Gilbert Scott in the Gothic Revival style; this is a memorial to Prince Albert, who died of typhoid. The design was approved in 1863, and the monument unveiled in 1871 (ten years after Albert's death). Figures on the corners of the monument, reflecting different corners of the globe.

Looking down Avenue Foche towards the Arc de Triomphe. The avenue was previously called Avenue du Bois de Boulogne (where one end of the road ends), and was renamed after Marshal Ferdinand Foch (1851-1929) in the year he died, Taken in the 16eme Arrondissement (Arrondissement de Passy).

Found in the Place du Carrousel, on the site of the former Tuileries Palace, at the west of the Louvre. The arch was built between 1806-08, designed by Charles Percier (1764-1838) and Pierre François Léonard Fontaine (1762-1853). The design was to mark the military victory of Napoleon Bonaparte (Emperor Napoleon I), and act as the gateway to the imperial residence in the Tuileries Palace (which was later destroyed in 1871 during the Paris Commune). The arch was originally topped with a quadriga (chariot led by 4 horses) from Saint Mark's Cathedral in Venice (captured in 1798 by Napoleon), but these were returned in 1815 following Waterloo. A replacement quadriga designed by Baron François Joseph Bosio (1769-1845), this one showed Peace led by gilded Victories, representing the restoration of the Bourbons. Taken in the Palais du Louvre (Louvre Palace). The palais occupies the site of the original Louvre fortress (the name Louvre comes from "leower" a Frankish word meaning a fortified palace), dating from the c12th until its destruction in 1546 by Francis I. Francis built a new royal palace that consecutive monarchs added to, the last work by a Bourbon monarch was initiated in 1659, when Louis XIV ordered the creation of the eastern wing (1665–80), designed by Claude Perrault (1613-88). In 1678 the royal palace moved to Versailles, and the Louvre was turned into an art gallery. Napoleons I and III added to the complex; the former had the Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel built between the two western wings, and the latter added a new wing designed by architects Louis Visconti (1791-1853) and Hector Lefuel (1782-1850)

This Art Nouveau bridge was designed by architects Joseph Cassien-Bernard and Gaston Cousin and built by Jean Résal and Amédée d'Alby between 1896-1900. The bridge was named in honour of Tsar Alexander III, who had concluded the Franco-Russian Alliance in 1892. The bridge is an arch bridge with four 17-meter socles, acting as counterweights, atop of each of these is a large gilt statue. Taken in the 8e Arrondissement
paris artnouveau pontalexandreiii archbridge 8earrondissement francorussianalliance tsaralexanderiii josephcassienbernard gastoncousin jeanrésal amédéedalby 170912
